citations.narrative:
During review of incident reports maintained and provided by the facility representative concerning the animal interactive
exhibits, specifically in the aviary and non-human primate (NHP) exhibits, there were three (3) bites attributed to the 4-
year-old male neutered capuchin, Abu, and one (1) bite attributed to the adult male umbrella cockatoo, Nigel. These
incidents occurred over a two-and-a-half-week period.
**On April10, 2024, a young girl was feeding the capuchin when she became scared and was bitten.
**On April 3, 2024, a young girl was interacting with the capuchin when she was bitten on the finger.
**On March 29, 2024, a woman was bitten on the wrist by the capuchin while trying to prevent him from moving towards
her daughter as he was running around the enclosure.
**On March 27, 2024, a woman was bitten by the cockatoo during an interaction with birds in the aviary. Part of the visitor
group was left in the aviary while the attendant entered the primate room for an interaction with the capuchin.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
Correct by: May 23, 2024
Facility has begun updating their handling protocols and re-assessing interactions with the animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Marla Renshaw, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Lindsay Livingston, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
During review of incident reports maintained and provided by the facility representative concerning the animal interactive 
exhibits, specifically in the aviary and non-human primate (NHP) exhibits, there were three (3) bites attributed to the 4-
year-old male neutered capuchin, Abu, and one (1) bite attributed to the adult male umbrella cockatoo, Nigel. These 
incidents occurred over a two-and-a-half-week period.  
**On April10, 2024, a young girl was feeding the capuchin when she became scared and was bitten.  
**On April 3, 2024, a young girl was interacting with the capuchin when she was bitten on the finger. 
**On March 29, 2024, a woman was bitten on the wrist by the capuchin while trying to prevent him from moving towards 
her daughter as he was running around the enclosure.  
**On March 27, 2024, a woman was bitten by the cockatoo during an interaction with birds in the aviary. Part of the visitor 
group was left in the aviary while the attendant entered the primate room for an interaction with the capuchin.  
 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals 
and the public.  
 
Correct by: May 23, 2024 
 
Facility has begun updating their handling protocols and re-assessing interactions with the animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Marla Renshaw, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Lindsay Livingston, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
